file_metadata.authors: ["KONSTANTINOS SOUSOU NIS", "BURCU EROGDAN", "MICHAEL LEVIN", "JESSICA L. WHITED"]
file_metadata.title: Precise control of ion channel and gap junction expression is required for patterning of the regenerating axolotl limb

chunks.text: Axolotls and other salamanders can regenerate lost tissue after amputation or injury. Growth and morphogenesis are coordinated by transcriptional networks and biophysical properties like ion flows and voltage gradients. This study investigated the role of ion channels and gap junctions in limb patterning during axolotl limb regeneration.
chunks.chunk_summary: This study investigates the role of ion channels and gap junctions in axolotl limb regeneration.
chunks.authors: ["KONSTANTINOS SOUSOU NIS", "BURCU EROGDAN", "MICHAEL LEVIN", "JESSICA L. WHITED"]

chunks.text: Manipulating expression and activities of ion channels and gap junctions in axolotl limb blastema cells via retroviral infections of human Connexin 26 (Cx26), potassium (Kir2.1-Y242F and Kv1.5), and sodium (NeoNav1.5) ion channel proteins, along with EGFP control, revealed that Cx26 overexpression caused syndactyly, while ion channel protein overexpression resulted in digit loss and structural abnormalities. Exposing limbs to the gap junction inhibitor lindane also caused digit loss.
chunks.chunk_summary: Overexpression of Cx26 caused syndactyly, while overexpression of ion channel proteins resulted in digit loss and structural abnormalities, and lindane exposure caused digit loss.
chunks.authors: ["KONSTANTINOS SOUSOU NIS", "BURCU EROGDAN", "MICHAEL LEVIN", "JESSICA L. WHITED"]

chunks.text: The data suggest that manipulating native ion channel and gap junction function in blastema cells results in patterning defects, possibly by disrupting the regulation of gene expression, cell cycle progression, and migration due to altered ion flows and voltage gradients.
chunks.topic: Impact of bioelectric manipulation on limb patterning
chunks.chunk_summary: Manipulating ion channel and gap junction function disrupts limb patterning by altering ion flows and voltage gradients, affecting cellular processes like gene expression and migration.
chunks.authors: ["KONSTANTINOS SOUSOU NIS", "BURCU EROGDAN", "MICHAEL LEVIN", "JESSICA L. WHITED"]

chunks.text: Axolotl limb regeneration involves complex cell coordination within the blastema. While gene expression and biochemical signaling are known drivers of cell behavior, biophysical factors like ion-mediated electrical signaling also play a role in tissue-level patterning. Endogenous trans-epithelial electric fields are crucial, as reversing the current efflux from the stump after amputation causes regenerative failure.
chunks.chunk_summary: Biophysical factors, including ion-mediated electrical signaling and trans-epithelial electric fields, are crucial for axolotl limb regeneration.
chunks.authors: ["KONSTANTINOS SOUSOU NIS", "BURCU EROGDAN", "MICHAEL LEVIN", "JESSICA L. WHITED"]

chunks.text: Endogenous gradients of cellular resting potentials, established by ion pumps, channels, and pores, regulate growth and form in all cell types. Modulating these gradients can induce or augment regeneration in amphibian and mammalian appendages. Bioelectric states are tissue-level properties propagated via gap junctions, which connect neighboring cells and allow ion diffusion. Ion channels set resting potentials, while gap junctions regulate the topology of bioelectric networks by defining boundaries between cell fields with distinct membrane voltage potentials.
chunks.chunk_summary: Ion channels and gap junctions regulate bioelectric states, which are tissue-level properties crucial for growth and regeneration.
chunks.authors: ["KONSTANTINOS SOUSOU NIS", "BURCU EROGDAN", "MICHAEL LEVIN", "JESSICA L. WHITED"]

chunks.text: Changes in membrane potential can trigger cell functions like gene expression, cell cycle entry, and differentiation, all essential for regeneration. Altering ion flow and membrane potential can affect tissue patterning. For example, kenk5b and connexin43 regulate fin growth in zebrafish, while hyperpolarization induces ectopic eye formation in Xenopus laevis. Ion flow also influences morphogen gradients, as Kir2.1 regulates Dpp release in fly wings. Conversely, Shh and Wnt signaling activate connexin43, facilitating gap junctional communication and Ca++ oscillations for feather bud growth. Similar feedback loops exist between bioelectric circuits and Notch/Wnt signaling in Xenopus brain and planarian axial patterning.
chunks.chunk_summary: Bioelectric signals, including changes in membrane potential and ion flow, interact with morphogen gradients to regulate tissue patterning and regeneration.
chunks.authors: ["KONSTANTINOS SOUSOU NIS", "BURCU EROGDAN", "MICHAEL LEVIN", "JESSICA L. WHITED"]

chunks.text: Mis-regulated ion channels in human channelopathies cause morphological defects, including digit formation issues. Andersen-Tawil Syndrome (Kir2.1 mutations) leads to limb abnormalities like digit shortening and syndactyly. Other channelopathies with limb defects include Timothy syndrome (Cav1.2 mutations), Freeman-Sheldon syndrome (sodium leak channel mutations), and Temple-Baraitser syndrome (KCNH1 mutations). This study investigates the role of ion channels in patterning the regenerating limb, hypothesizing that changes in membrane potential are crucial for successful axolotl limb regeneration.
chunks.chunk_summary: Human channelopathies demonstrate the importance of ion channel regulation for proper limb development, motivating the study of ion channels in limb regeneration.
chunks.authors: ["KONSTANTINOS SOUSOU NIS", "BURCU EROGDAN", "MICHAEL LEVIN", "JESSICA L. WHITED"]

chunks.text: To test the hypothesis that electrogenic protein activity is important for regenerative patterning, the authors datamined expression of ion channels and gap junctions from existing transcriptomics data of axolotl limbs and found dynamic regulation during blastema formation and patterning. They then manipulated membrane potential in blastema cells by overexpressing human ion channel proteins (Kir2.1-Y242F, Kv1.5, NeoNav1.5) or gap junction protein (Cx26). These constructs have been previously characterized to modify bioelectrical states in other systems. Kir2.1-Y242F hyperpolarizes cells and triggers myogenic differentiation. Kv1.5 and NeoNav1.5 can induce ectopic eye formation in Xenopus. Cx26 facilitates constitutively permeable gap junctions, disrupting endogenous boundaries. Skeletal morphology analysis showed that overexpressing these proteins caused defects in digit number and morphology, suggesting their importance in limb regeneration.
chunks.chunk_summary: The study investigates the role of ion channels and gap junctions in limb regeneration by manipulating their expression in axolotl blastema cells and analyzing the resulting skeletal morphology.
chunks.authors: ["KONSTANTINOS SOUSOU NIS", "BURCU EROGDAN", "MICHAEL LEVIN", "JESSICA L. WHITED"]

chunks.text: Analysis of existing transcriptomic data from axolotl limbs confirmed that various ion channel and gap junction isoforms are transcribed during regeneration. Gene ontology analysis showed enrichment of ion homeostasis terms early in regeneration (12h-3d) and tissue development/morphogenesis terms later (7d-14d). The study focused on pattern formation rather than earlier regenerative processes, manipulating blastemas at 9 days post-amputation and assessing outcomes at 40 days.
chunks.chunk_summary: Ion channel and gap junction genes are dynamically regulated during axolotl limb regeneration, with ion homeostasis enriched early and morphogenesis enriched later.
chunks.authors: ["KONSTANTINOS SOUSOU NIS", "BURCU EROGDAN", "MICHAEL LEVIN", "JESSICA L. WHITED"]

chunks.text: Overexpressing ion channel proteins (Kir2.1-Y242F, Kv1.5, NeoNav1.5) in axolotl limb blastemas caused morphological defects in regenerated limbs. Control limbs (EGFP overexpression) showed few major defects, mostly minor carpal abnormalities. Kir2.1-Y242F overexpression resulted in digit loss or duplication in forelimbs and carpal abnormalities in hindlimbs. Kv1.5 overexpression caused distal element malformation, digit loss/truncation, or extra digit formation in forelimbs and fused/split carpals in hindlimbs. NeoNav1.5 overexpression led to digit loss/truncation or extra digit formation in forelimbs, syndactyly in hindlimbs, and carpal defects in both. These results suggest that ion channel misexpression disrupts limb patterning by affecting cell behavior.
chunks.chunk_summary: Overexpression of ion channel proteins in blastema cells resulted in various limb defects, including digit loss, duplication, truncation, and carpal abnormalities.
chunks.authors: ["KONSTANTINOS SOUSOU NIS", "BURCU EROGDAN", "MICHAEL LEVIN", "JESSICA L. WHITED"]

chunks.text: Overexpressing Cx26, a gap junction protein, also caused limb defects. Cx26 overexpression led to distal element loss/malformation and syndactyly in forelimbs, and syndactyly and carpal morphology defects in hindlimbs. This suggests that precise gap junctional communication is essential for limb patterning during regeneration.
chunks.chunk_summary: Overexpression of Cx26 resulted in limb defects, including distal element loss/malformation and syndactyly, highlighting the importance of gap junctional communication in limb regeneration.
chunks.authors: ["KONSTANTINOS SOUSOU NIS", "BURCU EROGDAN", "MICHAEL LEVIN", "JESSICA L. WHITED"]

chunks.text: Inhibiting gap junction function with lindane, a gap junction blocker, caused severe defects in regenerated limbs, including loss of carpals and digits or zeugopod malformation. All lindane-treated forelimbs showed severe defects compared to DMSO controls, which had fewer major defects. This further supports the importance of gap junction-mediated communication for limb regeneration.
chunks.chunk_summary: Lindane treatment, which inhibits gap junction function, caused severe limb defects, further demonstrating the importance of gap junctions in regeneration.
chunks.authors: ["KONSTANTINOS SOUSOU NIS", "BURCU EROGDAN", "MICHAEL LEVIN", "JESSICA L. WHITED"]

chunks.text: Endogenous patterns of resting potentials, established by ion channels and gap junctions, are crucial for development and regeneration. They modulate ion concentration gradients and enable long-distance communication via gap junctions. This bioelectric gradient instructs cellular functions like viability, proliferation, differentiation, migration, and gene expression, all critical for tissue patterning.
chunks.chunk_summary: Bioelectric gradients, established by ion channels and gap junctions, play an instructive role in cellular functions crucial for tissue patterning during development and regeneration.
chunks.authors: ["KONSTANTINOS SOUSOU NIS", "BURCU EROGDAN", "MICHAEL LEVIN", "JESSICA L. WHITED"]

chunks.text: RNA sequencing data from regenerating axolotl limbs revealed transcription of various ion channel and gap junction isoforms. However, the bioelectric state is not solely determined by gene transcription but also by channel gating and other physiological/biochemical signals.
chunks.chunk_summary: While gene expression data suggests the involvement of ion channels and gap junctions, the bioelectric state is regulated by multiple factors beyond transcription.
chunks.authors: ["KONSTANTINOS SOUSOU NIS", "BURCU EROGDAN", "MICHAEL LEVIN", "JESSICA L. WHITED"]

chunks.text: Challenging ionic homeostasis by overexpressing ion channel proteins (Kir2.1, Kv1.5, Nav1.5) or Cx26 resulted in limb defects, including digit loss, truncation, duplication, and syndactyly. The observed differences between forelimb and hindlimb defects might be due to variations in morphogenetic gradients and gene expression patterns.
chunks.topic: Impact of bioelectric manipulation on limb morphology
chunks.chunk_summary: Manipulating ion channel and gap junction expression disrupts limb morphology, potentially due to differences in forelimb and hindlimb morphogenetic gradients and gene expression.
chunks.authors: ["KONSTANTINOS SOUSOU NIS", "BURCU EROGDAN", "MICHAEL LEVIN", "JESSICA L. WHITED"]

chunks.text: Cx26 overexpression caused distal element loss/malformation and syndactyly, while lindane-induced gap junction blockade caused more severe distal element loss. This suggests the importance of precise gap junctional communication for limb regeneration, although other roles of these factors cannot be excluded.
chunks.topic: Role of gap junctions in limb regeneration
chunks.chunk_summary: Both overexpression and inhibition of gap junction activity disrupt limb regeneration, highlighting the importance of precise gap junctional communication.
chunks.authors: ["KONSTANTINOS SOUSOU NIS", "BURCU EROGDAN", "MICHAEL LEVIN", "JESSICA L. WHITED"]

chunks.text: The study suggests a role for precise control of ion channel and gap junction activity in limb patterning during regeneration, potentially linked to bioelectrical currents and membrane potential regulation. Further studies are needed to confirm the link between misexpression of these proteins and altered membrane potential in axolotl limbs.
chunks.chunk_summary: Further research is needed to elucidate the exact mechanisms by which ion channels and gap junctions influence limb regeneration, including direct measurement of membrane potential changes.
chunks.authors: ["KONSTANTINOS SOUSOU NIS", "BURCU EROGDAN", "MICHAEL LEVIN", "JESSICA L. WHITED"]

chunks.text: The mechanisms by which membrane potential influences limb regeneration could be at the cellular or tissue level. Maintaining ionic homeostasis is crucial for cellular functions like viability, proliferation, differentiation, migration, and gene expression. Signaling pathways like Shh, Fgfs, Bmps, Wnts, and Hox, important for tissue patterning, are connected to membrane potential regulation. For example, Andersen-Tawil syndrome (Kir2.1 mutations) causes morphological defects and alters neural crest marker expression. Kir2.1 misexpression also affects digit and wing patterning in mice and flies, respectively, with links to TGFb/BMP signaling. Kir2.1 is also involved in osteogenesis and chondrogenesis. Other potassium channels are implicated in developmental disorders with craniofacial and digital abnormalities. Shh and Wnt signaling promote gap junctional communication via connexin43, coordinating cell migration during feather morphogenesis. FGF4 influences Cx43 and Cx32 expression in limb buds. Future work should examine the expression of digit patterning genes in hyperpolarized/depolarized limbs, investigate cellular behaviors, and utilize transgenic axolotls with voltage indicator proteins for real-time monitoring of bioelectrical gradients during regeneration.
chunks.chunk_summary: Membrane potential influences limb regeneration through various cellular and tissue-level mechanisms, including regulating gene expression, signaling pathways, and cell behaviors, with future research focusing on specific gene expression changes and real-time monitoring of bioelectrical gradients.
chunks.authors: ["KONSTANTINOS SOUSOU NIS", "BURCU EROGDAN", "MICHAEL LEVIN", "JESSICA L. WHITED"]

chunks.text: The study's results suggest that blastema cells use precise bioelectric state modulation to orchestrate limb pattern formation. Disrupting these mechanisms leads to morphological defects. Future work should investigate the exact mechanisms connecting bioelectrical state and limb morphology during regeneration.
chunks.chunk_summary: Precise bioelectric state modulation is essential for limb pattern formation during regeneration, and disrupting these mechanisms leads to morphological defects.
chunks.authors: ["KONSTANTINOS SOUSOU NIS", "BURCU EROGDAN", "MICHAEL LEVIN", "JESSICA L. WHITED"]

chunks.text: All animal experiments were approved by IACUC. Leucistic axolotls were used, anesthetized with tricaine during amputation at the mid-stylopod level. Bones were trimmed, and limbs were harvested 10 weeks post-amputation for skeletal staining.
chunks.chunk_summary: Standard animal handling procedures were followed, including amputation, bone trimming, and limb harvesting for skeletal staining.
chunks.authors: ["KONSTANTINOS SOUSOU NIS", "BURCU EROGDAN", "MICHAEL LEVIN", "JESSICA L. WHITED"]

chunks.text: RNA-seq data from Stewart et al. (2013) was used to analyze ion channel and gap junction gene expression in intact and regenerating forelimbs. Genes with TPM > 1 at homeostasis were examined, and log2 ratios of TPMs relative to time zero were calculated.
chunks.chunk_summary: Existing RNA-seq data was used to analyze the expression of ion channel and gap junction genes during limb regeneration.
chunks.authors: ["KONSTANTINOS SOUSOU NIS", "BURCU EROGDAN", "MICHAEL LEVIN", "JESSICA L. WHITED"]

chunks.text: Retroviruses expressing human Cx26, ion channel proteins (Kir2.1-Y242F, Kv1.5, NeoNav1.5), or EGFP were produced and injected into blastema cells. Virus production involved transfecting HEK293 cells with the constructs, helper plasmid, and coat protein. Virus was collected, concentrated, and titered using HEK293 cells.
chunks.chunk_summary: Retroviruses expressing the target proteins were produced using standard transfection and concentration methods and then injected into blastema cells.
chunks.authors: ["KONSTANTINOS SOUSOU NIS", "BURCU EROGDAN", "MICHAEL LEVIN", "JESSICA L. WHITED"]

chunks.text: Regenerated limbs were stained with Alcian blue/Alizarin red to analyze skeletal patterns. Defects were classified as major (digit loss, syndactyly, polydactyly, distal element loss/malformation) or minor (carpal/tarsal formation defects).
chunks.chunk_summary: Skeletal preparations were stained and analyzed for morphological defects, categorized as major or minor.
chunks.authors: ["KONSTANTINOS SOUSOU NIS", "BURCU EROGDAN", "MICHAEL LEVIN", "JESSICA L. WHITED"]

chunks.text: Lindane (10mM in DMSO) was administered to axolotl housing water for acute gap junction inhibition.
chunks.chunk_summary: Lindane was used to inhibit gap junction formation during limb regeneration.
chunks.authors: ["KONSTANTINOS SOUSOU NIS", "BURCU EROGDAN", "MICHAEL LEVIN", "JESSICA L. WHITED"]
